image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: White weatherboard home with paint peeling off the fence and a for lease sign out the front

props.synopsis: Rebuilding high-rise public housing, building 80,000 new homes a year and more restrictions on landlords — what might Victoria's housing changes mean for you?

title.children: The Victorian government is making sweeping changes to housing across the state. So what does that mean for you?

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry into government response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been announced, but state and territory local lockdowns and border closures are likely to avoid scrutiny.

title.children: Lockdowns and border closures omitted in scope of inquiry into government COVID-19 pandemic response

image.altText: A burnt-out red car in the entrance of a tobacco shop.

props.synopsis: Police say they are closing in on the "main players" in an illegal tobacco trade which they believe is behind several tobacco store fires in Melbourne.

title.children: Police hunt 'main players' in illegal tobacco trade as Melbourne shop goes up in flames

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: A man on a bike in lycra rides along a road flanked by green bushes.

props.synopsis: A state parliamentary inquiry is warned of the dangers faced by vulnerable road users at a hearing in country Victoria, as the state's devastating road toll continues to climb.

title.children: 'You risk your life every time' on Victorian roads, cyclist tells safety inquiry

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: Julian Assange unites cross-party delegation in Washington to push for WikiLeaks founder's freedom

image.altText: A three-panel image showing a young, ginger-haired woman, a dark-haired man and a dark-haired woman.

props.synopsis: Ballarat is witnessing anti-trans demonstrations on a weekly basis but trans supporters say the protesters do not represent the regional city.

title.children: Ballarat attracts weekly anti-trans demonstrations, but the community fights back

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Collingwood's Mason Cox leaps high and takes the ball in one hand at a contest as players stand around.

props.synopsis: The AFL's preliminary finals weekend pits the league's two most consistent teams of the year — Collingwood and Brisbane — with the most in-form challengers — GWS and Carlton. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson break down how the games will be won and lost.

title.children: The leaders or the challengers? How two massive AFL preliminary finals will be decided

image.altText: Justin Trudeau and Narendra Modi shaking hands.

props.synopsis: Tension has grown since Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Canada was investigating "credible allegations" about the potential involvement of Indian government agents in the murder of Hardeep Singh Nijjar.

title.children: India tells students in Canada to exercise 'extreme caution' as relations worsen

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Bomb remains in dirt next to small signs with skull and crossbones on them.

props.synopsis: In a letter to the US government, a UN torture expert says cluster munitions — which are prohibited by more than 100 countries — "indiscriminately and seriously injure civilians both at the time of use and in post-conflict" and should not be used.

title.children: US urged not to give Ukraine cluster munitions which could 'remain dangerous for decades'

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: Lindsay May looking up at the camera holding a painted abalone shell

props.synopsis: As debate over the Voice continues around the country, locals in this remote South Australian community are focused on issues closer to home.

title.children: This town only has enough jobs for 15 per cent of locals. The community is working to change that

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: The country is transitioning through the largest building code changes in a decade. But what does this mean for home owners?

title.children: Building your dream home? Here's what you'll need to consider under new construction code changes

image.altText: A night vision image of a pet cat carrying native prey in it's mouth.

props.synopsis: An ecologist warns pet owners to keep predatory animals secure, after a cat is spotted on the Yorke Peninsula in South Australia posing a threat to recently reintroduced brush-tailed bettongs.

title.children: Pet cat caught on camera carrying native prey in national park home to precious endangered bettong colony

image.altText: Paul has dark hair and a beard and wears a blue jacket with white flowers on his lapel and a patterned bowtie

props.synopsis: Police have charged an 18-year-old Belmont man with the murder of 40-year-old Paul Grapsas, whose body was found hours after he left home for a late-night dog walk last Thursday.

title.children: Police charge 18-year-old man with murder of Geelong father Paul Grapsas

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: The ASX sheds 1 per cent in line with global markets after the US central bank stiffens its hawkish stance, while former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX sheds 1pc, former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US interest rates unchanged

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's more to the Chevron dispute on pay and working conditions at the energy giant's two LNG facilities in Western Australia. The Fair Work Commission (FWC) recommended an increase in certain allowances for employees, and said a committee would be set up to work over the next three months to list the skills required for staff to become eligible for promotions. Employees should also be paid to travel to attend training sessions, and Chevron must pay for their flights and accommodation if required, the commission said. Commissioner Bernie Riordan said "I strongly recommend that the parties adopt the recommendations … which will hopefully resolve these disputes." "In my view, the parties are close to achieving their desired outcome of registered enterprise agreements to cover the wages and employment conditions," Riordan said in the filing. "It would be a pity and very frustrating to simply throw out these agreed positions and have the parties return to their respective logs of claims for any future arbitration." Chevron and the unions said they would review the recommendations. The two sides have until 9am AEST on Friday to decide whether to accept the commission's recommendations.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fair Work recommends end to Chevron dispute

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not just our market that's fallen today. Japan's Nikkei is also more than 1 per cent lower. Technology heavyweights tracked their US peers lower after the Federal Reserve stiffened its hawkish stance with a further interest rate hike projected by the end of the year. The Nikkei had fallen 1.14 per cent to 32,647.72 by the midday break. Chip-testing equipment maker Advantest the biggest drag, shedding 2.34 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Japanese Nikkei also down 1pc

children.content: It's not just our market that's fallen today.
Technology heavyweights tracked their US peers lower after the Federal Reserve stiffened its hawkish stance with a further interest rate hike projected by the end of the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been several weeks now that about 500 workers at Chevron's liquefied natural gas (LNG) Wheatstone and Gorgon facilities in Western Australia's north have been negotiating a new agreement. Workers are into their second week of industrial action, including 24 hour stoppages. Both parties have been fronting the Fair Work Commission to try to strike a deal. But talks yesterday ended without a deal, with a Chevron spokesperson saying it's now up to a workplace tribunal to map a way forward. Chevron Australia said despite "meaningful negotiations" this week, unions at the Wheatstone and Gorgon facilities, which export about 7 per cent of global LNG, continued to ask for terms well above industry standards. "The ongoing lack of agreement reinforces our view that there is no reasonable prospect of agreement between the parties, " the Chevron spokesperson said. A spokesman from the offshore Alliance - the union representing the Chevron workers sent through this statement. "The negotiations before the Commissioner were useful and resulted in some concessions on both sides. However, the Offshore Alliance and its members want to secure an enterprise agreement that locks in industry standard terms and conditions and the offer made by Chevron at the conclusion of the negotiations failed to meet that standard. "Offshore Alliance members remain open to compromise, but Chevron must table an offer that doesn't have Chevron providing lesser terms and conditions of employment to its employees when compared to other employers in the sector." The Fair Work Commission, will meet on Friday to review the dispute.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron and its workers unable to reach a way forward on negotations

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Some experts are warning Australia's ambitions to have zero carbon emissions by 2050 need to be scaled up dramatically.

title.children: Reaching net zero by 2035 would take a 'gargantuan' effort. But these experts say our current 2050 target is just too far away

image.altText: A fair-haired Italian man and a dark-haired Italian man sit on rocks in a mountainous landscape eating bread with their hands.

props.synopsis: This Cannes Jury Prize-winning film set in the scenic Italian Alps is travel-porn worthy – but its central narrative about friendship and the loss of youthful idealism has clout.

title.children: 'Handsome Italians in chunky knitwear': This award-winning, wistful film oozes rustic chic

image.altText: Researcher digging things from underground.

props.synopsis: Archaeologists say they have unearthed the oldest wooden structure ever discovered, near Zambia's Kalambo Falls.

title.children: Wooden structure from before time of homo sapiens found in Zambia

image.altText: A computer screen with the Stayz website getting visited

props.synopsis: Local mayors say the Victorian government has short-changed the regions by promising them only 25 per cent of the funds raised by a levy on short-term accommodation, which will begin in 2025.

title.children: Tourist towns need more from Victoria's short-stay accommodation tax, regional mayors say

image.altText: Man in a suit stands for his bail hearing in front of a crowd of photograpers.

props.synopsis: Oscar Pistorius was eligible for parole in March and the double-amputee Olympic runner may have been wrongly denied early release from prison because of an error.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius may have been wrongly denied parole over error

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Hudson on the left and Magenta Marshall on the right.

props.synopsis: The WA Liberal Party's candidate in the Rockingham by-election apologises for asking a constituent to question his opponent whether she would resign from parliament if she fell pregnant.

title.children: Scheme to ask by-election rival about her pregnancy plans ends in 'regret' from Liberal candidate

image.altText: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal pose for a photograph ahead of the 2022 French Open final.

props.synopsis: Rafael Nadal pays tribute to Novak Djokovic after the world number one added a 24th major singles trophy to his collection following his victory in the US Open final last week.

title.children: 'Best in history': Nadal heaps praise on rival Djokovic

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Retired Test winger Drew Mitchell blames veteran coach Eddie Jones for putting the Wallabies in danger of missing the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

title.children: Ex-Wallaby unloads expletive-loaded criticism on Eddie Jones as World Cup campaign hangs by a thread

image.altText: Vapour pours from a mill chimney behind power poles.

props.synopsis: Western Australia confirms it will be the only state to not set an emissions reduction target for 2030, despite having the most work to do to bring its carbon output down.

title.children: There's one state where carbon emissions have risen since 2005. It's also the only one with no 2030 reduction target

image.altText: Elon Musks' face is pictured behind the logo for Neuralink.

props.synopsis: Elon Musk's brain-chip startup Neuralink says it will begin recruiting for the first human trial of its brain implant for paralysis patients after receiving approval from an independent review board.

title.children: Elon Musk's Neuralink to start human trial of brain implant for paralysis patients

image.altText: Richard Scolyer holds up his hands while speaking at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: Richard Scolyer is at the forefront of melanoma treatment and research, but a devastating cancer diagnosis of his own has made him the self-described "patient zero" in a new frontier of brain cancer treatment.

title.children: 'Nothing short of phenomenal': Cancer expert undergoing experimental treatment reporting promising results
